Bjarne Andersen wrote:
> Hi.
> 
> On page foo.bar there are links in javascript like:
> onclick="window.open('http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/2006/index.html', 'new_win')"
> 
> I'm using the org.archive.crawler.scope.DomainScope scoping model and don't want pages like this to be crawled
> 
> Is links like this counted in because of the "max-speculative-hops" and are there any way to avoid them ?

Yes, that link would be discovered as a 'speculative' ('X') hop. If 
'nobelprize.org' was not one of the target domains of the DomainScope 
(from the seeds), it would only be crawled because of 'transclusion'.

Setting the 'max-speculative-hops' to '0' should prevent this from being 
in-scope, but would affect all other 'X' hops as well. (All links found 
in Javascript, Flash, and other non-HTML content are usually 'X' type -- 
we don't know for sure if they're only followed when clicked 'L' or 
necessary to render their referrer 'E'.)

In CVS HEAD (and upcoming 1.10.2 release), ExtractorHTML has a new 
'extract-javascript' flag which, if set to 'false', will prevent all 
attempts to extract from Javascript inside HTML ('<script>' tags and 
'javascript:' URIs). (If you generally want to extract such links, but 
not on some problem sites, you could set this false only in an override.)

If you needed to get really fancy, it should be possible to exclude just 
links found inside 'onclick' (or other 'on___') attributes, using the 
'viaContext' value saved on discovered links and a custom exclusion 
filter (either in Java or inside a BeanshellDecideRule). Let me know if 
you need more information about this option.

Hope this helps,
